name: Creatine
summary: A naturally occurring compound stored in muscle and brain tissue that supports cellular energy production. Supplementation is widely used for athletic performance and is being investigated for neuropsychiatric and cognitive benefits.
description: Creatine is a nitrogenous organic acid synthesized from amino acids and stored primarily in skeletal muscle and the brain as phosphocreatine. It plays a critical role in the ATP-phosphocreatine energy system, rapidly regenerating ATP during high-demand states. Supplementation is well established in sports and exercise performance, but emerging evidence supports its potential for neuroprotection, antidepressant augmentation, cognitive enhancement, and neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s disease, ALS, and traumatic brain injury.

metadata.natural_source: Endogenously synthesized (arginine, glycine, methionine); dietary sources include meat and fish
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

primary_indications: Cognitive support in aging and neurological disorders
contraindications: Caution in patients with kidney disease
monitoring_required: Renal function (creatinine, eGFR) in at-risk populations

items: Adjunct for depression and mood disorders
Cognitive support in aging and stress

sections.text: Creatine enhances the ATP-phosphocreatine energy system, supporting rapid ATP regeneration during energy-demanding tasks. In the brain, it may enhance synaptic transmission, mitochondrial function, and resilience to oxidative stress, contributing to potential antidepressant and neuroprotective effects.

adult.note: Creatine monohydrate is the most studied and effective form.

sections.pediatric: Used in certain metabolic disorders under medical supervision; not typically recommended for healthy children.

sections.text: Performance effects: within 1 week with loading or 3–4 weeks with maintenance dosing; Cognitive/mood effects: typically observed after several weeks of supplementation.

serious: Rare renal stress in predisposed individuals

other: Monitor kidney function in patients with renal risk factors.

items.risk: Mixed evidence on interaction with performance benefits

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient evidence; avoid unless medically indicated
sections.pediatrics: Limited safety data; not recommended for general use
sections.geriatrics: Well tolerated; may support muscle and cognitive function

sections.text: No taper required; supplementation can be discontinued without withdrawal effects.

items: Creatine monohydrate has the strongest safety and efficacy evidence.
May augment antidepressant effects in treatment-resistant depression.
Neuropsychiatric research is ongoing in bipolar disorder, Parkinson’s disease, and traumatic brain injury.

items.label: Roitman S, Green T, Osher Y, et al. Creatine monohydrate in resistant depression: a preliminary study. J Clin Psychiatry. 2007
Persky AM, Brazeau GA. Clinical pharmacology of the dietary supplement creatine monohydrate. Pharmacol Rev. 2001

seo.title: Creatine: Beyond Sports – Cognitive and Mood Benefits
seo.description: Creatine is a well-studied supplement for energy metabolism, exercise, and emerging psychiatric uses. Learn about its mechanisms, dosing, and neuropsychiatric potential.
